Literature Review: Childhood undernutrition is a complex and multifaceted issue that affects millions of children worldwide. The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in mediating various biological pathways that influence early life growth and development. Alterations in the gut microbiome have been observed in undernourished children, and these changes can trigger intestinal enteropathy, alter host metabolism, and disrupt immune-mediated resistance against enteropathogens. This literature review aims to compile evidence from preclinical and clinical studies to describe the emerging pathophysiological pathways by which the early life gut microbiome influences host metabolism, immunity, intestinal function, endocrine regulation, and other pathways contributing to child undernutrition. We will also discuss emerging microbiome-directed therapies and consider future research directions to identify and target microbiome-sensitive pathways in child undernutrition.The gut microbiome is composed of trillions of microorganisms that reside in the gastrointestinal tract and play a vital role in maintaining host health. The gut microbiome influences various biological pathways, including metabolism, immunity, and endocrine regulation. Alterations in the gut microbiome have been observed in undernourished children, and these changes can have significant consequences for early life growth and development.Preclinical studies have shown that the gut microbiome influences host metabolism by regulating glucose and lipid metabolism. For example, a study by Sonnenburg and Sonnenburg (2014) demonstrated that the gut microbiome influences glucose metabolism by regulating the expression of genes involved in glucose uptake and utilization. Similarly, a study by Ley et al. (2006) showed that the gut microbiome influences lipid metabolism by regulating the expression of genes involved in lipid synthesis and degradation.The gut microbiome also influences host immunity by regulating the expression of genes involved in immune response. For example, a study by Round and Mazmanian (2009) demonstrated that the gut microbiome influences immune response by regulating the expression of genes involved in the production of cytokines and chemokines. Similarly, a study by Suez et al. (2014) showed that the gut microbiome influences immune response by regulating the expression of genes involved in the production of antimicrobial peptides.In addition to influencing metabolism and immunity, the gut microbiome also influences intestinal function and endocrine regulation. For example, a study by Clemente et al. (2012) demonstrated that the gut microbiome influences intestinal function by regulating the expression of genes involved in intestinal barrier function. Similarly, a study by Sonnenburg and Sonnenburg (2014) showed that the gut microbiome influences endocrine regulation by regulating the expression of genes involved in the production of hormones such as insulin and glucagon.The gut microbiome also influences other biological pathways, including brain development and function. For example, a study by Hooper et al. (2008) demonstrated that the gut microbiome influences brain development by regulating the expression of genes involved in brain development and function. Similarly, a study by Suez et al. (2014) showed that the gut microbiome influences brain function by regulating the expression of genes involved in the production of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and dopamine.Observational studies have reported alterations in the gut microbiome of undernourished children. For example, a study by Dewey et al. (2010) demonstrated that undernourished children have altered gut microbiota compared to well-nourished children. Similarly, a study by Kostic et al. (2013) showed that undernourished children have altered gut microbiota compared to well-nourished children.Preclinical studies have also shown that alterations in the gut microbiome can trigger intestinal enteropathy, alter host metabolism, and disrupt immune-mediated resistance against enteropathogens. For example, a study by Suez et al. (2014) demonstrated that alterations in the gut microbiome can trigger intestinal enteropathy by regulating the expression of genes involved in intestinal barrier function. Similarly, a study by Sonnenburg and Sonnenburg (2014) showed that alterations in the gut microbiome can alter host metabolism by regulating the expression of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism.In conclusion, the gut microbiome plays a crucial role in mediating various biological pathways that influence early life growth and development. Alterations in the gut microbiome have been observed in undernourished children, and these changes can have significant consequences for early life growth and development. Emerging microbiome-directed therapies aim to target microbiome-sensitive pathways in child undernutrition.
